title: Will Thailand hold general elections before 1 January 2018?
preds: The Military in Thailand likes being in control.There may be elections but they won't be honest and the people will not accept the military staying in control
I doubt anything will happen in the next week.

Deputy Prime Minister Wissanu Krea-ngam has brushed aside talk that the regime has given a signal for changes to be made to the organic law governing political parties in order to delay the general election and retain the regime's grip on power. Mr Wissanu insisted that the constitution stipulates time frames leading to the election tentatively set for November next year.
https://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/1379671/wissanu-dismisses-talk-of-poll-delay

References are still being made to the next election being held in November 2018
Thanks @Anneinak

http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/thailand-to-hold-general-election-in-mid-oct-2018-at-the-earliest-dec-2018-at-the "Thailand is expected to hold a general election in mid-October next year at the earliest or December 2018 at the latest, according to an Election Commission official.

Bangkok (CNN): Thailand's former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra fled Thailand for Dubai two days before a verdict was due to be delivered in a trial over rice subsidies, a highly-placed source in her Pheu Thai party said Friday. Yingluck left Thailand on Wednesday and is now "safe and sound" in Dubai, the source said. She was due to appear in court Friday but a warrant was issued for her arrest after she failed to show up.
Yingluck's brother Thaksin, who is also a former Thai Prime Minister, lives in Dubai and London in self-imposed exile to avoid corruption charges.
No further news has been released on Thai elections - therefore maintaining chance of 0%
http://www.chinapost.com.tw/asia/2017/08/17/500055/p2/yingluck-verdict.htm " . . . the next election promised by the junta to be held in the second half of 2018

http://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/nec-begin-registering-voters-it-missed-2017 "The National Election Committee said it will aim to register around 1.4 million of the nearly 2 million eligible voters it was unable to get on voter rolls last year . . . The electoral body will start adding new names . . . to the voter rolls from September 10 to November 9. “If an individual does not have their name in the 2017 voter registry, the individual cannot vote in the 2018 national election,” Bun Hok said.
~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Voter registration will continue through 11/9 for a 2018 national election:  got it!
https://asia.nikkei.com/print/article/284940 "Thailand is moving toward democracy, with a general election set to be held by the end of 2018. The election initially was promised for 2015."
It's now August and there's no indication of election-related activities in the news. Following consensus.

All reliable news sources are confirming that Thailand will not hold general elections before 2018 - until beginning of 2017, most newspaper and the Thai government itself was reporting the opposite but it seems clear that the current Thai leadership is aiming to hold elections in 2018. "One year from today, there'll be elections," Deputy Prime Minister Wissanu Krea-ngam told reporters from Reuters: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-politics-idUSKBN15N19M The (official) reason for the postponement: to pass election laws for democratic transition from military rule. http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/01/thailand-legislator-general-election-delayed-170102161345073.html However, if one wants to look into more depth of Thai politics, I can recommend this article http://thediplomat.com/2016/03/why-thailands-next-election-may-not-matter/ - the author asks rightly if the elections matter at all anyway as 'the crux of the problem in Thailand has not been the holding of the election itself, but the unwillingness of various groups to accept the outcome.'

Thailand's next election in exactly one year: deputy PM  Tanakasempipat (2017) Wed Feb 8, states that: An election to restore democracy in military-ruled Thailand will take place a year from now, the government said on Wednesday, affirming for the first-time widespread expectations a vote the military had promised for this year will be postponed. "One year from today, there'll be elections," Deputy Prime Minister Wissanu Krea-ngam told reporters. The military government that came to power in a 2014 coup had repeatedly said a general election would be held in 2017, even after the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej on Oct. 13 raised doubts about the timing, given a one-year period of official mourning for the revered monarch. Wissanu said the conclusion of the junta's election timeline could not be clearly set down as a new constitution, a key part of the junta's plans to restore democratic rule, is being amended (para. 1-4). Wissanu said on Tuesday the government had nearly finished the revision and would submit the amended version for royal endorsement by Feb. 18 (para. 7). The king has 90 days to approve it (para. 7-8). Tanakasempipat, P. (2017). Thailand's next election in exactly one year: deputy PM. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-politics-idUSKBN15N19M

After we have seen that Duerte was declaring martial law in the Philippines, yesterday, that forecasters claimed to have near zero probability, I have thought a lot about risk management in forecasting...
So I go a little bit with @Anneinak: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/508456

https://aecnewstoday.com/2017/thailand-english-language-news-for-may-22-2017/#ixzz4hyKfHcPY  The National Legislative Assembly (NLA) is currently examining the draft political party law and the draft electoral commission law. Both organic laws will be tabled for their second and third readings in the House next month. The two organic laws bring the prospect of a Thailand general election closer. The next two organic laws to be tabled will be the draft national strategies act and the draft reform procedures act. A draft law on criminal procedures for political office holders is expected to be submitted to the NLA by the Constitutional Drafting Committee (CDC) by the end of this month. • The Constitutional Drafting Committee (CDC) has advised that the 2017 Thailand Constitution requirement for a Thailand general election to be held within 150 days of all organic laws being approved  does not include the announcement of the results.
Dropping from one to zero because the government has slated elections for 2018 and I look forward to hearing about their next inevitable postponement.

Might be some sort of typo.  I think what this question really means is, "Will generals hold Thailand elections...?"  Well, they say they won't, and they're the generals.   On the other hand, one does look forward to a result in which every single winner, no matter the size of the majority, is elected in a Thai vote.  [My sainted mother always told me never to pass up a cheap gag.]
Elections are now set for 2018 and the new constitution signed on April 6th, intensifies state control
According to Military Junta in Thailand, they will held election in 2018

Are you kidding me? One must be excessively naive to give 2017 election any significant chance (or to even listen to public statements without massive grains of salt). I thought to give it 5% because everything can happen in life. But went for 0. As even the PM now says 2018. So 2018 is the earliest imaginable date....... 
http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/2087022/thailands-junta-lift-political-party-ban-2018-elections

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-king-constitution-idUSKBN1780VB "There are still many steps before a general election can be held, or even until a ban is lifted on party politics. According to the timeline set out in the constitution, it could be late 2018 before a ballot and unforeseen delays are still possible."

"Election due late in 2018 The general election will be held in November next year at the latest now that the date has been set for the promulgation of Thailand's 20th constitution, according to the roadmap set by the National Council..." Source: http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/1226960/election-due-late-in-2018 Note: This question can go on repeat next year.

I don't think this will happen because, basically, the military junta keeps pushing back elections and the new king seems to have no interest in how Thailand functions as long as he has his entertainment. Also, see links. The Thai legislature and junta have declared the elections will be in 2018. http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/01/thailand-legislator-general-election-delayed-170102161345073.html
http://www.theborneopost.com/2017/01/06/thai-junta-says-elections-will-be-held-in-early-2018/

That document allows for fresh elections, which, after multiple postponements, are now expected in 2018. 
http://www.economist.com/news/asia/21719474-it-claims-crave-national-reconciliation-while-continuing-persecute-political-opponents

Thailand's next election in exactly one year: deputy PM
"One year from today, there'll be elections," Deputy Prime Minister Wissanu Krea-ngam told reporters.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-politics-idUSKBN15N19M?il=0
According to latest news during January, the opposition is waiting that the elections are going to be delayed. Military communicates that they are on the road-map and the elections will be this year.
Interesting article about Thailand’s politics under the new monarch: http://www.dawn.com/news/1311920
why would they honor their promises when they have an iron grip on the country? Not too much of a chance.

Thailand to begin amending draft constitution on king's request
Political observers say the amendments requested by the king will likely delay the polls to mid-2018.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-king-constitution-idUSKBN15115D
Dropping, but not quite as far as other commenters. The military still wants the election sooner rather than later.
Per Reuters article posted by scholar and cat.

Long piece about legal issues. It's complicated. The conclusion is clear: "There's not going to be an election this year or early 2018. The next junta roadmap assurance will be for an election before 2020." http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/politics/1180297/roadmap-veers-off-course

The new king's recent tinkering with the proposed constitution gives the military a really good excuse to bump the election into at least 2018.  They aren't even pretending to be disappointed, although they prefer the royal strings to be pulled in a less public way.
Downing my prediction based on the DBrownian comment below.

See comment and link by @DBrownian and there's more: http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/thailands-new-king-rama-x-flexes-muscles/news-story/473210c4d55718778f570d70313d3be6 http://asia.nikkei.com/print/article/229561

King Vajiralongkorn’s decision to block the new constitution will delay the elections by several months, as the junta now has to make the necessary amendments to it. As the elections were scheduled for end of year this will move them way into 2018. http://www.economist.com/news/asia/21714298-all-wrong-reasons-thailands-new-king-rejects-armys-proposed-constitution
I am catching up on the news that the government has said it needs more time before an election.

Landing midway between original forecast and pure uncertainty in response to further statements from government leaders about elections. See this op-ed for a reasonable take on why we can't take them at their word: http://www.khaosodenglish.com/opinion/2017/01/07/rule-iron-fist-lie-without-shame/
Dropping to 50/50 on contradictory signals reported in this article: http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/12th-times-the-charm-thai-army-chief-vows-no-more-coups

NLA member Boonthanom has a more specific timeframe (March or April 2018) set Jan 2017, compared to a handwaving "late 2017" set by the PMs office two years ago. Inclined to agree with the more accurate estimate. Bet the PMs office could "schedule" an election in 2017 and count it as fulfillment.

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/01/thailand-legislator-general-election-delayed-170102161345073.html One member of the legislature says the election will be put off; some other (anonymous) sources say a delay would be jake with them, although for different reasons.  The PM's office says the 2017 date is firm.  Coming down a bit, pending clarification if any.

Although all of the new election laws are not implemented yet; seems that there is adequate time, and there is no real threat to the current government.
Outcome seems well managed by the governing junta.  Controls the Senate.  Opposition parties, if they collaberate, could challenge; but does't seem likely, as conflict between the two main opposition parties led to the military intervention.
http://www.khaosodenglish.com/politics/2016/12/31/post-election-thailand-return-guided-democracy-scholar-says/

"Netiwit and others like Suranand Vejjajiva, former secretary general to Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, also cited the need to complete the funerary rites for King Bhumibol as a reason why elections may be forestalled. Labor activist Wasana Lamdee said it’s difficult to know despite the junta’s roadmap, as political parties are in disarray and must adjust to new election rules as well as rules regulating political parties and politicians. None has been finalised yet." From article: http://www.khaosodenglish.com/politics/2016/12/27/thailand-2017-elections-bigger-protests/
The elections will of course be rigged to the extent possible, but that isn't part of the Q.
Increasing due to Prince invited to assume throne. http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/11/28/world/asia/ap-as-thailand-king.html?_r=0

Thai election roadmap on course: deputy PM
http://in.reuters.com/article/thailand-politics-idINKBN13J0BN
New elections no longer threaten military leadership, due to constitutional changes.

Raising 5% as Thai government's "road map to democracy" doesn't seem to have been affected too much by the old king's death. Still not confident all will go as planned though. Deputy Prime Minister Wissanu Krea-ngam says, "The road map will be followed, but there may be some factors that cannot be seen today. There could be some changes or adjustments. However, today we insist there will be election in 2017,” http://www.thejakartapost.com/seasia/2016/11/24/thailand-2017-election-maybe-no-new-government.html
Here is the road map, as I understand it:  The new Constitution is promulgated - this hasn't happened yet, possibly due to king's death. 
After this, 10 organic bills are to be completed within eight months of the promulgation. The first four bills cover political parties, the election of MPs, selection of senators and the Election Commission. I'm not sure what the other six might be, but an eight month time frame suggests that ratification of these measures may not be straightforward. 
Then, and only then, can the government formally announce that a five month window has been set for the holding of a general election. 
If I've understood this process correctly, it's easy to envisage a "change or adjustment" which might set things back a month or two.
The military made clear that it wants to install a parliament elected by the people. It could still exercise control through the senate and different military-appointed committees.
The military government has committed to submit a a constitution for Royal Endorsement (something of a formality) and it is a strong indicator for the elections to be held in Nov 2017.
Looking more likely based the new charter which benefits the junta and had popular support.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-politics-idUSKBN1330UW
The generals will have their fake constitution approved in plenty of time to stage their fake elections next year.  Isn't democracy wonderful?  (This question will not be on the exam.)
Bumping up to 85 on this news report: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-politics-idUSKBN1330UW

I think they will put on at least some show elections. The generals seem to think it important, as long as it doesn't get out of control.  Their control, that is. There will eventually be a contest to select a prime minister.  The result will, of course, will be a Thai.

After Bhumibol's death in October, crown prince Maha Vajiralongkorn has indicated he wants to take at least a year for mourning. Given that the generals want a smooth transition, this means that there are two possibilities: 
1. They wait for him to ascend to the throne, and then start thinking about when to hold elections. This would be too late for elections in 2017 probably. 
2. They organize the elections before Vajiralongkorn ascends to the throne. This would give them November and December to organize the elections in 2017.
There is also the odd chance that Vajiralongkorn refuses to become king. In this case, chances of general elections happening in 2017 really depend on the timing of his announcement.
Are generals actually elected in Thailand?  Ooops--never mind.

Think its a question of whether the current junta feels it needs to hold the elections to consolidate its power. They have already passed a new constitution guaranteeing a permanent military influence in running the country. The death of the king leads to the question of succession, which has been put on hold seemingly for a year. Seems unlikely that general elections would be held before the new king's coronation. That would not leave enough time for the elections before 2018. The fact that 2018 has already been mentioned by General Prayuth as a possible year for the elections supports this.
Thhey will keep promise and hold election, but it won't be fair, real or sovereign.

Year of mourning, legal and constitutional changes required, past track record of delayed elections lead me to think chance is less than 50%. Media reports claim elections will still go ahead in 2017 but government officials declined to comment.
Given the departure of the King and the unpopularity of the heir, I doubt those in power want the election to happen earlier.
Adjusting down because I think I was overconfident before and because I did not understand the importance of the monarch and the year of mourning.

Polls suggest a slight majority of Thai citizens back the newest charter, which gives the junta a lot of power. Any new elections are less likely to threaten the status quo by a civilian leader http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/thailand-to-hold-elections-in-2017-junta-chief-confirms , but promises to hold elections have slipped in the past, and this is all a year away. Without further research I feel this has less than a 50 percent chance, for now.

due to time line and funeral
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/359867
Adjusting down as I just heard the King's funeral will not take place for a year. I assume the elections will not be held before then, and there is not much time from then to 2018.

Updated to reflect the mourning for the King, which will last a year. Allowing for time for the new coronation, it could complicate matters somewhat and at the very least provide a convenient excuse to put elections off.

Although the Thai government said that elections for the next Prime Minister will remain on schedule I don't see elections being held during the year of mourning for King Bhumipol. The combination of the peoples reverent respect for King Bhumipol and the Thai military's possible desire to stay in power will likely keep the elections from being held in 2017. I lived in Thailand for three years and the peoples reverence is real, it is hard to imagine the country wanting to fiddle with politics at this time.  I imagine elections taking place once the year of mourning has passed; October 2018 marks the end of the mourning period thus the small likelihood of elections prior to Jan. 2018.
It has officially been stated by the military junta that it intends to continue its path toward elections despite the death of its monarch.

The constitution, which is favourable to the military, was approved in the referendum. The death of the king probably clears the way for an election in the sense that the military wanted to be in control of  the situation after his death. Had he survived well into 2017 my prediction would be far less certain. The only unknown here is whether former PM Thaksin will start agitating again, but I think he is now a spent force.

Country is reeling from death of long-standing king. Lots of power vacuums. Recent history (and visits) show it to be quite an egalitarian country in terms of business, travel to and from Australian continent, school system, country values.  I think Thailand will opt to hold elections and that might work for the country.

I think the reason why the election will take place this time is because the military got its constitution approved. However, the military does have a bad track record and the king died. Also, there might be protests that prevent the elections from happening, but the military could probably squash those.

Almost surely.  The military have said so.  They have not yet announced who will win, but that should be along shortly.  Meantime, the Crown Prince is holding off on the coronation until he finishes his anger management and rehab programmes.   It is illegal to say this in Thailand.  Guess I'll have to vacation elsewhere next year.
As @ulfelder commented, in spite of Thai Kings death junta is pressing ahead with elections.
Affirming at 80 percent on word that military reiterated commitment to elections in 2017 after king's death: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-king-idUSKBN12H08D

Thai king's death will not delay election: media
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-king-idUSKBN12H08D?il=0

http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-37670834
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-37672088 The Crown Prince has asked for his coronation to be put off a year on account of how sad he is.  The caretaker government probably wants to put on some sort of show elections around the time he takes over--sort of a double-legitimacy ploy.  The elections will almost surely be rigged, but they'll most likely happen.

With the new Constitution that ensures that the Army will continue to be able control the Government I am not sure why the announced election plans would need to be postponed. I would assume that with the new Constitution the Army would want to hold the election. I guess the extended period of mourning could be used as an excuse (but why do the Army need an excuse?) Or the delay and confusion of when the new King will take over or be crowned could be used as an excuse. The only reason for not holding the election is that the authorities might be afraid of loosing, This does not seem to apply in this case.
Military junta will have an excuse to postpone elections beyond 2018.

The King is dead...as expected? Uncertainty over what this might mean for Thailand's economy and politics (see links) suggests that Prayut's upbeat promise to hold 2017 elections should be taken with a grain of salt. Not sure yet how this one might play out, but international media widely suggesting that a royal handover provides an (expected?) excuse to defer the election date.
http://www.economist.com/news/asia/21708728-country-holds-its-breath-thailand-tenterhooks-over-kings-health "The death of the king, if it comes soon, would provide the generals with the perfect excuse to delay a new election. Indeed, the army’s desire to secure an orderly royal handover seems to have been one of the reasons it took power in the first place." 
http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=11728702 (AP) "In a report, the Eurasia Group said his passing would lead a general election scheduled for 2017 to be pushed back to 2018."
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/10/13/without-king-bhumibols-unifying-presence-thailand-may-be-headed-for-even-greater-instability/ "Given the intensity of the crackdown, which occurred as Bhumibol became sicker and sicker, it seems likely that the military sensed that it had to consolidate its power before a less popular monarch took over. And despite its promise of elections next year, the junta announced a full year of mourning for Bhumibol, throwing that eventuality into doubt."
Considering the legitimate uncertainty over a royal succession, GJO consensus seems unreasonably high. In a few months time it might look good, but I don't think it does right now.
Updated given mourning period will be over prior to election period
Updating because of the King very poor health.
Adjusting upward as the King's health problems may lead to elections sooner rather than later.

The major risk is a delay is if the king dies close to the election date in 2017 and a period of mourning delays elections into 2018. Otherwise I expect that elections will take place in line with current suggested timeline by the military.
With the military in firm control of the country and the electoral process, a general election in 2017 is probable
The king is very sick and the interim military rule has been on-going since 2014.  It's time to move on.

Army chief and acting Prime Minister Prayut has promised an election in late 2017. However, previous election dates have slipped so it is unclear whether this is a reliable comment. However with the military achieving its desired result in the constitutional referendum this year, there will be less political incentive to delay another election, knowing that no party can dominate the result as happened in the Shinawatra era. The military will retain significant power over Thai democracy in any case, even with a new election. With increasing international pressure coming from the EU, USA and others, as well as increasing domestic frustration with the current limbo, an election looks highly likely in 2017.

The military needs this election to give the appearance of a democracy and to move forward with their economic plans. If they can control it through intimidation, like they did the constitutional referendum, then they will hold elections. Only massive civil unrest could derail this.

Seems to be decent support for the military in Thailand, no need for them to be too afraid. See no reasons why they wouldn't organise elections, especially under the new military drafted constitution.

In April 2014 the Constitutional Court ruled that the election was unconstitutional because the vote had not taken place on the same day nationwide. Following an agreement between the Election Commission and Yingluck's government, the fresh elections were set for 20 July.  However, the elections were cancelled after a coup d'état in May deposed the elected government and installed a military government known as the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO), led by General Prayuth Chan-ocha, then-Commander in Chief of the Royal Thai Army. The NCPO, when taking power, declared its intention to hold general elections after carrying out reforms and promulgating a new constitution. Shortly after the coup, Prayuth said that elections would likely be held "by the end of 2015". By late 2014, however, several government officials had said publicly that elections would not be held until 2016, around mid-year. In May 2015, Deputy Prime Minister Wissanu Krea-ngam said that elections would now be held “around August or in September” 2016, after the government announced its intention to hold a referendum on its draft constitution, which would likely be held sometime in early 2016. In June, Prayuth said that he was willing to stay in office for another two years if people "wanted him to", following a push by the National Reform Council (NRC), a government body, to hold a vote on whether or not the government's reforms should be completed before elections were held. This would mean general elections might potentially not be held until early 2018, but a few days later distanced himself from the NRC's initiative after facing backlash for his remarks. This, however, left the door open to the "completion of the reforms" under another government that would also see elections further postponed, if the NRC's initiative succeeded.
__________________________
COMMENTS: Perhaps not in 2017, or before 2018

Saying the right thing is easier than doing the right thing, so not reading too much into Prayut Chan-o-cha's "commitment" to November '17 election. Happy to be well below consensus at this early stage as there are plenty of reasons why a popular vote might be deferred once again. Still, there's a low bar for what might constitute a Thai "election" so not prepared to offer worse than 2:1.
This Q does not require free, fair or open elections.  Just elections.  No problem.
Upgrade slightly that there maybe elections being held prior to 1 January 2018.

Elections were supposed to be held in 2015. Then 2016. Now it is 2018. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next_Thai_general_election Skeptical elections will be held by 1 January 2018. But I do think elections will be held. Voting for the charter means there will be a general election late next year or early 2018 
http://www.scmp.com/week-asia/article/2018057/why-no-one-wants-rule-thailand-other-military Prime Minister Gen Prayut Chan-ocha has confirmed that the National Council For Peace and Order (NCPO) has plans to return democracy to the country, assuring that the general election will be held late next year. 
http://news.thaivisa.com/thailand/gen-prayut-general-election-to-be-held-in-2017/155398/

I think the junta already did its thinking about whether or not to hold elections next year; that thinking included concerns about the king's health and various other uncertainties; and that thinking resulted in the November 2017 date. The bigger question are how free those elections will be and whether or not Pheu Thai will be allowed to compete, but that's not what we're being asked here. So I'm starting at 80 and expect to revise upward with the passage of time if there are no contrary announcements.

well, they've said they will, and they didn't have to, so I'm somewhat inclined to take the junta at its word. They did also recently hold a referendum to approve a new constitution enshrining a decent chunk of military power, so it's understandable that they feel able to hold elections, secure in the knowledge that nothing too terrible can happen (from their perspective). The complicating factor here is the health of the King, who is 88 and ailing. He may not last the year, and if he does it seems quite probable that he passes away some time during 2017. How that would affect any scheduled elections, I don't really know. Obviously the interests of the Thai military & monarchy are quite closely interlinked. The Crown Prince lacks his father's popularity and to a degree I think we can expect the military to sort of hold his hand throughout the first few years of his reign. But what that means in a practical sense, it's not clear.
With the August referendum giving more power to the military and the elections being postponed multiple times already I think this probability is 50-50 at best.

Election currently scheduled for November 2018.  The new constitution gives the military strong control over the political process.  Even though the main political parties do not support the constitution, and demonstrations against the elections seem probable; the military control may lead to stable elections. The military political party, "National Council for Peace and Order" (NCPO) has a newly approved constitution.  The NCPO will appoint an 8-10 person panel to select a 250 member senate, which will have power to approve the PM and to issue no confidence votes against future elected governments. Although the main political parties are centered around a northern "rural" party and a southern "Bangkok" party, the military has needed to intervene regularly, the last coup to end political violence was in 2014.
